subhead: With no majority to back him in the Assemblée Nationale, Prime Minister François Bayrou has governed from a precarious position. He has held on, so far, thanks to a fragile agreement with the Socialists to re-examine the unpopular 2023 reform of the pensions system.

subhead: The targeting method, which is banned in Europe, with rare exceptions, by the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), continues to be used on Elon Musk's social network, according to a study by the NGO AI Forensics.

headline: G7 rallies behind Ukraine after Trump's sudden exit
subhead: Hosting the summit, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney welcomed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Tuesday and announced $1.47 billion of military support, including drones and helicopters, for Ukraine.

headline: Is it ever a good idea to… wear your clothes backwards?
subhead: In fashion, as in life, it is important to know the lines you should not cross − or else, to do so deliberately.

headline: The US refusal to intervene in Syria in 2013: A French trauma
subhead: 'The Transatlantic Divorce' (3/5). On August 31, 2013, as French warplanes were en route to Syria to launch a joint operation with the US against the regime of Bashar al-Assad, which had used chemical weapons against its own people, Barack Obama decided to delay, leaving France alone and powerless.

headline: Trump hastily leaves G7, lashes out at Macron
subhead: The American president once again made clear his rejection of multilateralism amid escalating tensions between Israel and Iran. 'Emmanuel always gets it wrong,' he said of his French counterpart.

headline: UK government reverses course and launches national inquiry into 'grooming gangs'
subhead: After a damning audit by a senior civil servant, Prime Minister Keir Starmer confirmed that the networks of sexual predators who operated for decades in the United Kingdom would be subject to a public inquiry.
